doc.title: JPM | Jiangxi Copper Beat, Lithium Bull vs Bear, Chalco Raise PT, Energy Transition & Daqo, Steel news & CNOOC Today
doc.source_uri: 2025-08-28/JPM APAC COMMODITIES Jiangxi Copper Beat Lithium Bull vs Bear Chalco Raise PT Energy Transition Daqo Steel news CNOOC To_2025-08-28

passages.text: Good morning, last day of APAC earnings (Finally!!). Jiangxi Copper beat overnight, with Net Profits \(+20\%\) y/y which were a \(10\%\) beat to JPM and \(\sim 65\%\) of bbg full year consensus. Stock is likely to be up at open, but reminded us on how weak smelting saying "TC/RC spot prices steadily decreased, with spot quotes even falling into significantly negative territory". We prefer the copper miners Zijin & CMOC.

The lithium debate reignited yesterday, with Yongxing (one of the 8 affected mines in Yichun) regaining their clay mining license (SMM, MySteel). Whilst the risk of lithium suspension is not resolved (given its a clay license from earlier, not full lithium), the equities sold off. Bears argue this sets up the mines to gradually come back in 3 months; and any lack of newsflow will see the lithium prices fall back given producer lock ins - the bulls were louder: arguing that conversion of porcelain to a full lithium license could take upto a year, and september \(30^{\mathrm{th}}\) (miners submit reserve docs) is the beginning not the end of the uncertainty. We'd highlight shorts on the lithium space haven't quite gone away - Tianqi & Ganfeng at \(15 - 17\%\) of FF shorted, so whilst the medium term outlook is still fairly negative with a large surplus, the stocks could continue to run into next month.

Lots in Energy land too, \(50\%\) tariffs on india went into effect yesterday with Modi meeting Putin & Xi this weekend. Crude's (Brent \(+1\%\) now to \(\) 68\() been stronger on this as well as bullish draws in Cushing. We are hosting CNOOC for a group meeting in HK today at 10.20am (mandarin only), let us know if you'd like to join.

Finally in Steel, some mixed headlines with Reuters reporting that China will be cutting steel production in 2025 & 2026. No numbers given, but we were already expecting \(3 - 5\%\) cuts. On the flip side, Toyota lowered steel sheet prices, which could later lead to lower crude steel contract prices for Nippon Steel, JFE & other suppliers.

- LEARNINGS FROM EARNINGS: Metals & Mining Takeaways Calls with our Australia & Asia Teams (Details below) - Monday & Wednesday- JIANGXECOPPER: Strong Beat on Net Profit, but Smelting still a concern- ENERGY TRANSITION: 10 Fresh Takes on Energy Supply (link); Alan & Hannah Marketing in Singapore next Week (Ask to join, Sep 3-5)- DAO: 1H25 NDR re-affirms our positive thesis (Alan Hon note)- CHALCO: Raising PT, expecting Payout hike to \(40\%\) by Year End, strengthening Aluminium supply chain (Avery Note)

JIANGXI COPPER (UW): Strong on Net Profit, but Smelting still a concern.

- Net Profits \(+20\%\) y/y at RMB 4.5B (IFRS) and Rmb 4.2B (PRC GAAP), which is a \(10\%\) beat to JPME and represents \(\sim 65\%\) of BBG Full Year Estimates. Interim Dividend of Rmb0.4, representing about a \(30\%\) payout, in line with last year's interim payout. Copper cathode production 1.2m tonnes \(+2\%\) y/y; so beat largely driven by copper prices which have been strong this year.- On Smelting: "TC/RC spot prices steadily decreased, with spot quotes even falling into significantly negative territory". Reminder that less than \(10\%\) of JXC's processed copper is its own copper concentrate; so TC/RCs & trading the longer term drivers.- Whilst earnings are strong from low base, we remain UW & prefer the Copper Miners Zijin & CMOC where earnings have grown \(50 - 60\%\) y/y. Expect stock to be up at the open.
CHALCO (OW): Raising PT, expecting Payout hike to \(40\%\) by Year End, strengthening Aluminium supply chain (Avery Note)

- Chalco-A/H's shares fell by \(1 - 4\%\) yest (vs. HSI -0.8%) despite an inline 1H25 result and a payout ratio hike. We believe the sell-off was mainly due to profit taking after a \(+54\%\) YTD run (vs. HSI 27%) and a miss on the potential payout hike as expected by some investors.- We expect Chalco to further increase its full-year payout ratio to \(40\%\) . Management has also raised its capex guidance to Rmb20bn for the next few years and will focus on securing overseas bauxite resources. We are positive on Chalco's growth outlook as it strengthens its integrated aluminum supply chain after China reaching the 45mt aluminum capacity cap.- Avery revises up FY25-27 earnings forecasts by \(5 - 7\%\) to reflect the positive aluminum price outlook. Our revised Chalco-A PT of Rmb10 implies FY26E P/B of 2x and P/E of 12x. Our Chalco-H PT of HK\(8 is based on a 26\%\) average 3-month A/H premium. Maintain OW
DAQO: 1H25 NDR re- affirms our positive thesis (Alan Hon note)

- Alan hosted an NDR meeting with Daqo's management team on August 28 and came back with a positive view: (1) management expressed a positive 3Q operating outlook, with increase in production volume and polysilicon price, and decrease in production costs; (2) management is constructive on the "anti-involution" (excessive competition) initiative, as they already saw polysilicon prices recovering to above production costs, while more policy measures (i.e. polysilicon sales and production restriction, industry consolidation fund) may be announced going forward;- Market Share & Buybacks: management is confident that Daqo may recover to its previous market share levels in the mid term, as they see room to lift utilization, assuming a stable price outlook. Daqo announced Usd 100mn share repurchase program on August 26 2025, on the back of a promising outlook into 2H25.- We believe there is a chance that Daqo Cayman may dispose some of its shares in Xinjiang Daqo and use the proceeds to buy back its own shares, which may narrow the valuation gap and enhance the controlling rights of Daqo Cayman's shareholders to Xinjiang Daqo. We maintain our OW rating on Daqo (DQ US).
APAC ENERGY TRANSITION: Ten Fresh Takes on Clean Energy Supply (Alan & Hannah Note)

- The road to a clean energy future is long (and uncertain). While the energy transition remains an overarching theme, history has shown that renewable energy build-out at scale does not necessarily translate into returns at all points of the value chain. Industry cycles, technological advancement, and geopolitics all come into play.- We give 10 answers to questions relating to the transition on three main topics: 1) Which transition value chains are in supply tightness or emerging as important ones? 2) Where are geopolitical risks less well understood? 3) Which transition
technologies will be the next game changers?
- JPM-covered stocks that emerge as our top picks include: Bannerman Energy (BMN), CATL-A, Hyundai Electric, Hyosung Heavy, ILU, LG Chem, LG Energy Solution, Orient Cables, Sieyuan and Tenaga
